sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: What are you doing?

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: Watching TV.

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: It’s rare not seeing you reading a book.

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: What’s on the tv?

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: ...I don’t know.

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: So you... you didn’t watch it?

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: I watched it. I just... don’t care enough about what’s on it.

sentences.name: Narator-Participant
sentences.sentence: It’s some random news about increasing car prices. It doesn’t concern Will nor Anna. But she puts the TV on that anyway.

sentences.name: Narator-Participant
sentences.sentence: Even though it doesn't make her sad or happy. It's just... distracting. It’s better than silence.

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: I bought you some bread.

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: Thanks.

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: Is the food still bad?

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: I think it will stay bad even after ten years.

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: Haha... I can see that.

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: But I'm starting to get used to it. It’s not that bad now.

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: I see. If you need something good other than bread, just tell me. I think I’m allowed to bring some food other than bread here.

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: Hmm... As long as it is healthy-

sentences.name: Narator-Participant
sentences.sentence: Healthy. At this time, whether it's Will or Anna, neither of them like this word.

sentences.name: Narator-Participant
sentences.sentence: The word always stops whatever they’re doing.

sentences.name: Narator-Participant
sentences.sentence: Making the air awkward. Sometimes, even a little tense.

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: But if you already bought some, just put it in the fridge. I’ll get some later.

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: Oh... Yea, you can get some later. I’ll just do that.

sentences.name: Narator-Participant
sentences.sentence: The light from the window starts to get yellow. While it becomes a little bit brighter, the shadows also become a little bit thicker.

sentences.name: Narator-Participant
sentences.sentence: The tray is not fully open. So most of the room is almost plain dark. That includes Anna.

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: It’s starting to get dark . . .

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: Yeah... It’s almost past six now.

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: How long can you stay here?

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: I don't know, probably until nine. But I can just wait until the nurses kick me out.

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: That’s going to be more entertaining than watching that TV. . .

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: Really?

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: Yeah.

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: What will you do after I leave?

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: Hmm... You bought some food, right? I guess I'll empty the fridge first.

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: That’s not like you. I thought you would finish all those books in one night. Or think of something interesting

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: What kind of reading speed do you think i have haha.

sentences.name: Narator-Participant
sentences.sentence: Anna looks at the pile of books by her side and then out the window. She might be trying to find something interesting in her head, but she stays silent for quite some time.

sentences.name: Narator-Participant
sentences.sentence: Will starts cutting some bread while he waits for her answer.

sentences.name: Narator-Participant
sentences.sentence: However, even after the lights start to fade, she keeps looking out the window and stays silent.

sentences.name: Narator-Participant
sentences.sentence: It’s like she can't think of anything. Even though normally, she would just say or do something so random out of the blue.

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: So . . . did you think of something interesting?

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: Hmm... This is a hard question.

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: Well, you don't have to answer if you don't have any answer.

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: Oh yea, Chloe said the renovation is almost finished.

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: Really? She said the library would be renovated too, right?

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: Yeah. We can go there after you leave. That’s something interesting that we can look forward to.

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: Yeah. . . maybe I'll find a new book in those libraries now.

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: That’s right, You always find a book interesting.

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: Because all of them are interesting.

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: Really? I don’t find cooking books interesting.

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: You can always find some weirdly interesting food in them, right? That’s what makes them really interesting.

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: Hmm. . . If you say so.

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: So... That's it. The first thing I'll do is visit the renovated library. It’s also been a while since we helped Chloe around the orphanage.

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: Yeah. . .That is something that we can look forward to.

sentences.name: Narator-Participant
sentences.sentence: The two are silent. They are both looking at the TV. It’s still talking about the car prices.

sentences.name: Narator-Participant
sentences.sentence: But just like Anna, Will doesn’t care. As long as both of them watch the TV--or anything--together, then the detail doesn't matter.

sentences.name: Narator-Participant
sentences.sentence: Both of them are silently looking at the TV until it’s completely dark outside.

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: Do you remember what you said that day?

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: What day?

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: You said you want to live for someone else. You said you no longer want anything for yourself, so you want to live for someone else.

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: Ooh... Yeah, I did say that.

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: What will you do if you can't live for me anymore?

sentences.name: Narator-Participant
sentences.sentence: Anna delivers her question like it’s some small talk. She is even still munching bread on her mouth.

sentences.name: Narator-Participant
sentences.sentence: However for Will, that’s the scariest question he ever heard. A “What if” question.

sentences.name: Narator-Participant
sentences.sentence: A question about something that might or might not, so it might not matter at all in the end.

sentences.name: Narator-Participant
sentences.sentence: But still, Will doesn’t want to entertain it.

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: Where is this coming from?

sentences.name: Anna
sentences.sentence: Will . . . I . .

sentences.name: Narator-Participant
sentences.sentence: Anna was about to say something. Something that Will needed to hear. Something really important. Something about the future.

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: Anna?

sentences.name: Narator-Participant
sentences.sentence: However, she didn’t say anything. Instead, she’s holding her own body. Tightly.

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: Are you okay?

sentences.name: Will
sentences.sentence: Wait I'll call the doctor.

sentences.name: Narator-Participant
sentences.sentence: Will understands what’s going on and runs outside to call for the doctor. The Doctor arrived with the nurses to do her treatment.

sentences.name: Narator-Participant
sentences.sentence: It was just like any other day.” Everything seemed fine but little did he know, It was their last moment together.

sentences.name: Narator
sentences.sentence: Couple hours after her treatment, more and more nurses with equipment came to Anna’s room.

sentences.name: Narator
sentences.sentence: Will was powerless and can only watch from a distance.

sentences.name: Narator
sentences.sentence: Anna suffered from complications that led to organ failure.

sentences.name: Narator
sentences.sentence: Before he knew it, She was gone. Lying in bed lifeless.

sentences.name: Narator
sentences.sentence: Anna was dead.
